sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying coil
message_1: A 100-turn circular coil with a radius of 0.2 meters carries a current of 2 amps. Calculate the magnetic field at a point located 0.1 meters away from the center of the coil on its axis.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at a point located 0.1 meters away from the center of the coil on its axis, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a circular loop:

B = (μ₀ * I * N * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, N is the number of turns, R is the radius of the coil, and x is the distance from the center of the coil along its axis.

Given the values:
I = 2 A
N = 100 turns
R = 0.2 m
x = 0.1 m

Plugging these values into the formula:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * 100 * (0.2 m)²) / (2 * ((0.2 m)² + (0.1 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) T * 100 * 0.04 m²) / (2 * (0.04 m² + 0.01 m²)^(3/2))

B = (3.2π × 10^(-5) T) / (2 * (0.05 m²)^(3/2))

B = (3.2π × 10^(-5) T) / (2 * 0.01118034 m³)

B = (3.2π × 10^(-5) T) / 0.02236068 m³

B ≈ 0.00004504 T

The magnetic field at a point located 0.1 meters away from the center of the coil on its axis is approximately 0.00004504 Tesla.
